title: Slavery
content:
It is now possible to control cockroaches (The so called robo-roach) by attaching electrodes to their antenae. It is also possible to control rats to a great deal by using electrodes implanted into their brains. Our knowledge of the mind and its relation to the brain increases steadily it two areas, neuroscience and charlatanry. (Including magicians, propagandists and con men.)

We can be manipulated to a greater deal than ever before, and that most likely can only increase. There are those who would love to exert full control over people for their own ends, and this to a much lesser degree seems to be routine. Yet often we are not aware of it at all, subtle, in the background manipulations and suggestions preserve the illusion of free will.

So the question I ask is, is a slave still a slave if they don't know they're enslaved?

title: Re: Slavery
content:
It must be very interesting to truly believe that you have no free will, it's just a hair's breadth from fatalism, and I don't think anyone actually truly believes it.

The question of whether 'society' masters us is a complex one; 'society' is a lovely term bought up and used as a straw man, sort of a universal oppressor, 'if I want to do it but can't, society is oppressing me.' It is closely related to our natural instincts. some of the most fundamental foundations upon which our society is built are instinctive; the old dogma that animals are amoral has long since been disproved.

I do believe the Victorians had an interesting view on determinism, only humans had free will, animals were 'm,eat machines'; even if you cut them open alive (And this was done.) any signs of pain were merely instinctive results of damage, they didn't 'feel' it.

I think it would be terrible if we were only machines that thought we were free, I can imagine no worse torture.

title: Re: Slavery
content:
From an absolutist standpoint --yes.

However, no one knows absolute truth. So, if we do not know we are slaves, then from an relative standpoint, we are not slaves.

This goes back to "free will v. predetermined fate."

Free will is the ability to what we want; we can do, and still be "controlled." If we are controlled to want something, and we do the thing that we want --is not that both free will and predetermined fate? Someone else has predetermined what we will want' but nevertheless, we want it and get it.


Whether you believe in theism or atheism, we are have both a free will or a destiny. The universe makes us who we are; therefore, we are given a destiny. However, we have free will in that we can always make choices.

The only way to have pure free will is to be above the laws of nature and have not been made by nature; otherwise, we are bounded by this universe.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
